column10: COMMENTS (either add comments here or using the comment function in a given cell. Do not write in the cell itself!)
column13: Number of coauthors from non-academic institutions
column14: Number of coauthors from governmental organizations (USGS, etc)
column15: Forecast spatial scale (point, multipoint, regional, national, global)
column16: If spatial scale is "point" or "multipoint": geographic coordinates from google maps (see notes)
column17: Forecast ecosystem: forest, grassland, freshwater, marine, desert, tundra, atmosphere, agricultural, urban, global, other
column18: Forecast class: biogeochemical or organismal (population or community)
column19: How many forecast variables are discussed in the paper
column24: If specified: more detailed description of model (e.g., Bayesian hierarchical, machine learning, named model (e.g., PROTECH), etc)
column25: Model covariate class(es) used in this study: meteorological, physical, chemical, or biological
column26: Does the paper explicitly identify that random effects were included? (y/n)
column27: Does the paper explicitly talk about latent variables, using this terminology? (y/n)
column32: Are multiple modeling approaches compared (NOT including null models)? (y/n)
column36: What type of null model (e.g. climatology, persistence)
column38: Time step of forecast output (in days)
column39: How often are new forecasts produced (in days)
column41: Model training period mentioned in paper? (y/n)
column43: Iterative forecast (i.e., data updating forecasts iteratively)? (y/n)
column44: What technique of data assimilation? (e.g., KF, enKF, refit, update IC, etc)
column45: Latency of observation data for assimilation (response variable). If not provided, mark "unspecified." Convert units to days
column47: If uncertainty is propagated: Is uncertainty propagation analytic or ensemble-based?
column48: What sources of uncertainty were incorporated?
column56: If at least two categories of uncertainty were partitioned, what was the dominant source of uncertainty?
column57: If the dominant source varies by forecast horizon, season, etc. please describe here
column60: Paper states that forecast was evaluated (y/n)
column61: Forecast evaluation results reported in paper (y/n)
column62: List all skill metrics used (e.g. R2, RMSE, bias, MAE)
column63: Is forecast performance assessed at multiple forecast horizons (results must be reported in paper/supplimental info)? (y/n)
column64: How many forecasting cycles are evaluated/assessed, with the results reported in the paper? (PLEASE READ NOTES HERE)
column65: How many total forecasting cycles are included for that variable in this paper (both those that are evaluated and those that are not)
column66: Maximum forecast horizon such that the forecast is better than the null model (out of any models used). Provide answer in days
column68: Maximum driver latency (latency of the driver with the longest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column69: Minimum driver latency (latency of the driver with the shortest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column70: Temporal coverage of data used to create this forecasting paper (in days; your best guess is fine here)
column71: Is new data (driver and/or observations) available to the model in real time (<24 hours from collection) without any manual effort when the system is working as intended? (y/n)
column73: Repository in which forecasts are archived
column74: Paper specifies that driver data are publicly available to reproduce the forecasts (according to the paper)
column77: Partnership w/ stakeholder in forecast development mentioned in paper (y/n)
column78: Forecast being used by stakeholder according to paper (y/n)
column79: Type of end user (general public vs institution)

column10: If we are excluding papers that forecast using the same data that the model was built with, this one probably doesn't count. This one is hard because they say they are assimilating data every 3.35 days, but we have to assume that this data was also used to build the models. Also, supplement has some justification for why they were forecasting within the calibration data record (they don't expect out of sample data to dramatically change their findings). Second opinon??
